feed.title: topposts.net
feed.subtitle: @topghost's post-cohost post host, built with octobug

entry.title: We are always using RSS again

content.p: via natalie, in reply to me:

blockquote.p: I've been surprised how many people I've seen posting about how they're using RSS again. I guess even when talking about "the heyday of RSS" I was assuming that it was mostly more people joining and not using it than people stopping that caused its decline. I for one have been using RSS pretty much daily since the early 00s.

content.p: I would say I fall off of daily RSS reading and then hop back on something like 3-4 times a year and have been since Google Reader died in 2013. It didn‚Äôt help that most of the people I knew personally stopped blogging (tho I‚Äôm also LARGELY guilty of that‚Äî I have been in the 3-to-4 posts a year camp on my primary self-hosted blog) and so my RSS feeds are mostly journalism, news, some weird accumulated tumblr pages, the random people I follow but don‚Äôt know who HAVE been blogging faithfully all this time, and (as the newsletter rebirth exploded and Feedbin added support for them) all the email newsletters I‚Äôm over-subscribed to.

So I‚Äôve been a paid user of Feedbin since something like 2015? I love it, but I also like to do a lot of things in my life and am definitely overcommitted to work and hobbies and family/housekeeping. Things fall by the wayside and as Cohost became a decent way for me to feel ‚Äúaware‚Äù of what was happening online I fell back into one of my periods of less RSS reading.

As Cohost was wrapping up I subscribed to almost every feed I saw people linking to, putting them in a new folder in Feedbin for just them. When I added the feed I put their Cohost username at the end in parentheses, but last night I realized that I wanted to flip it‚Äî I put @username at the front and then put all their carefully considered blog titles in parentheses after that. That small change makes me feel a little bit closer to everyone, as silly as it sounds. (I don‚Äôt consider this blog to have a ‚Äútitle‚Äù per se, btw‚Äî I think topposts dot net is fine for now)

PS I‚Äôm hoping by the end of the weekend I‚Äôll have working h-entry post embeds like Natalie does!! It‚Äôs so cool to see it working at the link at the top of the post and if you haven‚Äôt checked out her blog overall you really should!

entry.title: after talking to my brother today

content.p: I realized that I think brat is an album about narcissism and that your current feelings about its place in our culture will probably determine how you feel about the music
something I will say that has been very nice about using RSS again... going back to reading "oldest first" and having read/unread status. fight me
realizing today that the next step is to build a little RSS feed reader to give myself a "timeline"... shit
like do I already have a feed reader? yes! But there are so many other feeds in there that aren't people I know posting and I want to put the posting in one place!

entry.title: NTS Guide To Video Game Water Levels

content.p: https://youtu.be/WIWHNmcz-2k
NTS saw an amateur scene pop up on YouTube and said ‚ÄúI want that for me‚Äù

The blog post I was reading to try to figure out how to deal with the GitHub API‚Äôs requirement of base64-encoded data used the cheese emoji as some of its example data. I still haven‚Äôt fixed the bug so the poor cheese emoji will render like üßÄ
via graham:

blockquote.p: Today, my friend and I launched another new version of our puzzle game named Wizard Sokoban (working title). You can play it on itch.io for free, though it works best on a computer using firefox:

content.p: Go try out Wizard Sokoban! I got to level 13 the day after it was released and at that point it‚Äôs really unfurling into something more complex. I‚Äôm excited to play more!

entry.title: (wandering back into my group chats in a daze tomorrow morning)

content.p: MY FRIEND: whoa, we haven't seen you since like 2022. Where have you been?
ME: I... I... don't remember?

me, a 20-year-old, watching a 65-year-old person struggle to remember a childhood memory: heh, wow. skill issue I guess. not me, I've got this little thing called BRAIN TRAINING, I just do these every day and you'll never catch me looking like that. sucker
me, a 40-year-old, seeing something about ZZT: goddammit
guy who just happens to get really into blogging on October 1, 2024, without understanding what compels him
Tagged: #make up a guy
something I believe strongly is that you cannot skip track on Fatboy Slim's "Weapon of Choice". Once it starts playing, you have to listen to the whole thing
My friends<sup style="color:#527cf9;">[who?]</sup> should be allowed to add Wikipedia-style superscript notes to my posts
Tagged: #octobug (feature requests)

had a truly sick idea last night revolving around combining short-term cookies with JavaScript setTimeouts in order to fake long-polling (because you have to have GitHub API credentials in order to poll the GitHub repo) and then realized the only user who needs long-polling to auto-refresh is... the person who has API credentials
image posts... I need them

the site upgrades are piling up, I should really backport them to octobug ü§î among some post editor improvements (better mobile support!) NEW posts should have a new permalink structure while OLD posts retain their old URLs (to hopefully avoid bombarding feeds with "new" posts, and to avoid breaking what I'm sure are hundreds of links to my first ~25 brilliant posts)
Tagged: #octobug (meta)

entry.title: Printer with a heart of gold

content.p: are so much higher when deleting the post requires deleting a file from a git repo üò∞
hopping into the group chat to tell the squad how non-attached I feel today

I timed badly the delivery of a new phone (my old one was from 2020 and had had its battery replaced twice‚Ä¶ I need a bigger battery, apparently) and its accompanying case so I was carrying it around for the last 4 days with no case and it was kind of terrifying.
The new case has arrived and it‚Äôs a huge relief to know that I am at least somewhat protected from fucking up my phone now
it‚Äôs starting to feel like a website in here
honestly writing vanilla javascript to do things that still "feel good" feels like doing the saddest magic trick, but attracting the most hardcore audience. For my next trick, useful OpenGraph tags
and then it didn't again when I posted whatever that was. Third time's a charm?

there's this weird compulsion where the moment I think I'm making something that might be interesting, I want to polish it to a shine in a way that will make it possible for other people to use it. Despite the fact that it will require an intense and detail-oriented effort to go back and revisit almost every decision, definitely every cut corner, and figure out the "right" way to do it. the error cases to handle. the worries that if I let the software fail, it could hurt someone else.

It sucks! It sucks to feel that weight for absolutely no reason, despite the fact that what you are making is mid, that your knowledge is cobbled together from a bizarre bombardment of information that you've exposed yourself to over your career, both technical and political, that realistically no one cares and if someone does it's because they're already doing the same thing for themselves, or hopefully will someday.

I have to write things into the box and risk them getting posted to the internet in order to test if the software I wrote is working. That's a terrible idea. Automated tests, non-production environments, there are so many ways to make this not be a necessity. And even if not, I can still go delete the file from the repo if I want.
Tagged: #so what , #who cares
and when it posts to Github... we clear the form. hopefully
I'm posting to production again in order to test something locally. yes it's a nightmare
Tagged: #octobug (meta)
Tagged: #one letter off , #has anyone done this
It gets the list of tags from the server when you open the post editor
And then as you type it shows the tags you've already used so you can more easily "do a bit" that you've done before, and safely put it in the filing cabinet drawer where it belongs.
